"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." "Congress finds that the Middle Rio Grande bosque in Albuquerque, New Mexico is the largest continuous cottonwood forest in the Southwest, an old inhabited area, home to pueblos, and a vital habitat for migratory birds. It provides water to many in New Mexico and should be maintained to protect endangered species and the river flow while being more accessible to the public. Environmental restoration is crucial, and the Corps of Engineers should reestablish hydrologic connections where possible." The Corps of Engineers aims to enhance accessibility to the Middle Rio Grande bosque, prioritize environmental restoration, and reestablish hydrologic connections for healthy vegetation growth. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "critical restoration project" as a project that will provide immediate ecosystem restoration benefits, "Middle Rio Grande" as a section of the Rio Grande in New Mexico, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Army. The Secretary will conduct critical restoration projects along the Middle Rio Grande, selecting projects based on feasibility studies and utilizing existing studies and plans. Local participation is required, consulting with public and private entities active in ecosystem restoration in the Rio Grande watershed. Cost-sharing agreements must be established before project implementation. The Secretary will conduct critical restoration projects along the Middle Rio Grande, selecting projects based on feasibility studies and utilizing existing plans. Before project implementation, cost-sharing agreements must be established with non-Federal interests, requiring them to pay a portion of the total costs and provide necessary resources for the project. The Secretary will conduct critical restoration projects along the Middle Rio Grande, selecting projects based on feasibility studies and utilizing existing plans. Non-Federal interests are required to pay a portion of the total costs and provide necessary resources for the project. The critical restoration project will cover operation, maintenance, repair, replacement, and rehabilitation costs, with recreational features not exceeding 30% of the total project cost. Non-Federal funding will cover any additional recreational features beyond this limit. The non-Federal interests are responsible for paying up to 30% of the total project cost for critical restoration projects along the Middle Rio Grande. Any recreational features beyond this limit must be funded by the non-Federal interests. They can receive credit towards their share of design or construction costs if the work they perform is deemed integral to the project by the Secretary. SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $10,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 2004, and necessary sums for fiscal years 2005 through 2013.
